entry.value: This page features a variety of different graphically centred controls in Rapid.

Throughout this demo application we have gone into detail about the different actions in Rapid, but have not gone into detail about the different controls. From this page and moving forward we will be providing details on each control in Rapid.

Controls are the building blocks of Rapid, and every single Rapid app is made using controls in many different ways. They provide the front-end appearance of your app and they are highly customisable using CSS in either Rapid Design or Rapid Admin. It is even possible to create your own Rapid controls with bespoke and unique functionality, which can be done by going into the back-end of Rapid. These bespoke controls can handle extra functionality that is not readily available in Rapid, but is entirely possible to have within your app.
Going back to basics, we will begin by showcasing the more simple, everyday controls in Rapid that anyone with any level of web experience can recognise.

Our first control is likely to be the control that is used most commonly out of every single other control, and you are looking at it right now! The text control allows you to freely enter text, set a format, and set itself as a label for other controls used in validation. All controls in Rapid can be provided a name, which can then be used to reference the control later on when we want to manipulate the data or assign it something.

Keeping to the theme of text based elements, the next control we are going to look at is the link control. As you'd expect from a link, it allows you go to external URLs or another page within your Rapid applications. The link control allows you to set the link text, whether it opens an external URL or another page in your app, and sets whether to open this link in a new tab or on the same page. Below we have two link examples. One links to an external website and the other directs you to another page on this demo app.

Moving on from text based controls but keeping with the general theme of simplicity, another control you will be very familiar with is the button control. Used on almost all of the pages in this demo app, the button control allows you to set actions with the click event. The label sets what message the button displays, titles set readability for screen readers, and glyphs let you set a logo onto the button. Setting a glyph will also reveal different glyph options.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

Following on from buttons we are now going to cover the more graphical controls in Rapid, starting with the image control. The image control is as you'd expect. You have the ability to upload an image to be stored in Rapid, or select an image from those that have been uploaded. Images can have titles that display whenever someone hovers over them, and alternate text that displays if the image does not load or if someone is using a screen reader.

Next on the image list is the glyph control. Glyphs can be used in many different ways to illustrate something. Whilst small to begin with, they can be freely resized, coloured, and the like using CSS. Glyphs use a library of popular icons used to illustrate a variety of points, and they can be attached to many other controls in Rapid. Glyphs can also be set to spin on the spot.

The final graphically oriented control we are going to look at is the signature control. Most suited for mobile and tablet applications, the signature control provides a canvas area that can be drawn in, using either your finger or mouse. The pen colour can be adjusted and pen thickness can be set in one of three thickness options.

This page has covered some of the more basic, but graphically centred, controls in Rapid. Some of these controls you will find you use a lot more often than others, for example you will find yourself using a lot of text controls, but maybe not so much signatures or glyphs. The beauty of Rapid is that these lesser used controls can be switched off in Rapid Admin, meaning their code will not be loaded into your application. This will make your app even more lightweight! Pages will load slightly faster and less code will be in the page source files. On the whole, you will likely not notice a difference, as Rapid is already highly optimised, however for that extra bit of speed you can remove unused controls from your application. Moving on from here we will be showcasing some of the other commonly used controls and gradually show more complicated controls.
